Nightclub Cat Announces Mayoral Bid on Platform of Fondant and Fury

By Bartholomew "Barty" Butterscotch, Editor-In-Chief

In a move that has sent ripples through our confectionary city, Flapjack Fitzgerald, a tuxedo cat of questionable origin and proprietor of the infamous nightclub 'The Velvet Sponge', has declared his candidacy for mayor. His platform, unveiled atop a rapidly melting ice cream cake soapbox, promises "a sweet deal for everyone" and a total overhaul of our crumbling cookie infrastructure.

Fitzgerald, himself a structurally ambitious seven-layer cake, has criticized incumbent Mayor Crumble for his "stale policies." The core of Fitzgerald's plan is the "Great Frosting Initiative," a controversial proposal to use industrial quantities of royal icing to patch the city's notorious potholes—a move structural engineers have called "deliciously doomed."

"Is it fiscally responsible to build a new hospital out of Battenberg? No. Is it hilarious? Yes. The choice is clear."

Polls show a deeply divided populace. "I'm worried," said local resident Victoria Sponge, a concerned pound cake. "My child's school is a gingerbread house. One heavy rain and it's mush. We need stability, not sprinkles." Others are energized by Fitzgerald's chaotic vision. "Finally, someone's addressing the shortbread sidewalk issue," cheered a macaroon who wished to remain anonymous.

The election, scheduled for this fall, promises to be one of the most unpredictable in our city's history. This reporter, for one, is stocking up on forks and antacids...

Mayor Crumble's campaign, meanwhile, has been built on a message of 'proven ingredients.' His supporters point to the successful implementation of the Marzipan Monorail and the low unemployment rate among candy-makers. "We can't risk our city on a whim and a whisker," said Crumble's campaign manager, a stoic fruitcake. "Flapjack Fitzgerald is all style and no substance. Literally. He's mostly meringue."

As the race heats up, so too does the city—both politically and literally. The Department of Public Works has issued a level 3 melt warning for all nougat-based public seating. The Daily Mousse will continue to provide tasteless, I mean, tasteful coverage as the story develops.

This Whole Election is Half-Baked

An Op-Ed by Barty Butterscotch

I've been a journalist for twenty cat years. I've covered the Great Catnip Bust, the Red Dot Riots, the scandal of the Phantom Pooper. I thought I'd seen it all. I was wrong. This mayoral race between a nightclub-owning cake-cat and a sentient pile of crumbs is an insult to our collective intelligence. One candidate wants to govern with frosting, the other thinks progress is a slightly less stale scone. It's a lose-lose situation, and I'm losing my appetite.

Letter to the Editor

From a Concerned Cherry Bakewell

To the editor, Am I the only one who sees the problem with electing a candidate who is, by his own admission, "mostly mousse"? What happens when we have a heatwave? Do we have a contingency plan for a molten mayor? I demand answers. My taxes are not for funding a city-wide air conditioning unit just to keep our leader from turning into a puddle.
